'''Eddie King''' (April 21, 1938 – March 14, 2012) was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p93987|pure_url=yes}}|title=Eddie King |author=Eugene Chadbourne |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> ''[[Living Blues]]'' once stated "King is a potent singer and player with a raw, gospel-tinged voice and an aggressive, thick-toned guitar sound".<ref name="KCBX"/> He was noted as creating a "straightforward style, after [[Freddie King]] and [[Little Milton]]".<ref name="Encyc">{{cite book
| first= Gérard
| last= Herzhaft
| year= 1997
| title= Encyclopedia of the Blues
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= [[University of Arkansas Press]] 
| location= [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]], [[United States]]
| isbn= 1-55728-452-0
| page= 126}}</ref>

==Life and career==
King was born  '''Edward Lewis Davis Milton''' in [[Talladega, Alabama]], [[United States]]. His parents were both musical, with his father playing guitar and his mother a [[gospel music|gospel]] singer. King learned basic guitar riffs from watching from outside the window of local blues [[Nightclub|clubs]], and was inspired by the playing of [[Muddy Waters]], [[Howlin' Wolf]], and [[Little Walter]].<ref name="AMG"/> He grew up playing alongside [[Luther Allison]], [[Magic Sam]], [[Junior Wells]], [[Eddie C. Campbell]], and Freddie King.<ref name="KCBX">{{cite web |url=http://kcbx.net/~sloblues/jan01.htm |title=Eddie King & the Swamp Bees |author=San Luis Obispo Blues Society |date= |work= |publisher=Kcbx.net |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref><ref name="MNB">{{cite web |url=http://www.mnblues.com/review/eddieking.html |title=Eddie King |author=Ray M. Stiles |date= |work= |publisher=Mnblues.com |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>

He relocated to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], in 1954, and his diminutive stature and the influence of [[B.B. King]] led to him being referred to as 'Little Eddie King'. Given a break by [[Little Mack Simmons]],<ref name="MNB"/> he first recorded under the tutelage of [[Willie Dixon]] and, in 1960, played on several tracks recorded by [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]].<ref name="AMG"/> He also recorded with [[Detroit Junior]].<ref name="Encyc"/> Also in 1960, King had a single released by [[J.O.B. Records]], "Shakin' Inside" / "Love You Baby".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/job.html |title=The J.O.B. Label |author=Robert L. Campbell, George R. White, Robert Pruter, Dr. Robert Stallworth, Tom Kelly, Jim O'Neal, and Armin Büttner |date= |work= |publisher=Hubcap.clemson.edu |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>   He then became the guitarist backing [[Koko Taylor]], a role he undertook for two decades.  Separately forming Eddie King & the Kingsmen in 1969, King moved to [[Peoria, Illinois]], in the early 1980s. Since the early 1990s, King's backing [[musical ensemble|ensemble]] were known as the Swamp Bees, and his output has incorporated Chicago blues, [[country blues]], [[blues shouter]], and  [[soul music|soul]].<ref name="AMG"/>

His debut album, ''The Blues Has Got Me'' (1987), was issued by the [[Netherlands]] based [[record label]], Black Magic, and later re-released by Double Trouble.  It featured one of his sisters, Mae Bee May, on vocals. 

In 1997, King recorded ''Another Cow's Dead'', which got a [[Blues Music Award]] for 'Best Comeback Blues Album'.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="KCBX"/> It was arranged by [[Lou Marini]].

His songwriting credits include "Kitty Kat", described by one [[music journalism|journalist]] as "hilarious".<ref name="AMG"/>

King died in Peoria, Illinois, in March 2012, at the age of 73. In October 2012, the Killer Blues Headstone Project, a nonprofit organization, placed a headstone on King's unmarked grave at the Lutheran Cemetery in Peoria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lamazablues.blogspot.com/|title=La Maza Blues - Eddie King|publisher=Lamazablues.blogspot.com|accessdate=March 14, 2012}} From [[Bruce Iglauer]]: "I'm sad to report the death today of Eddie King, longtime guitar player with Koko Taylor's Blues Machine and Chicago blues veteran. Eddie died in Peoria; he had been in declining health for a long time. Sweet, nice guy and a true bluesman. He will be missed".</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/pjstar/obituary.aspx?n=edward-milton&pid=156522479 |title=Obituary - Edward Milton  |author= |date=March 17, 2012 |work=Peoria Journal Star|publisher=Pjstar.com |accessdate=March 18, 2012}}</ref>
